print_settings.Notes:: Beyond that, you want to print pretty hot and very slow.  I printed this at 40mm/sec, but the perimeters were printed at 20mm/sec.  If the dropper bulb is not water-tight (usually leaking at the corners) you can always use a drop of superglue to seal it up.

description.text:
This was an experiment mostly to see if it is possible to print a flexible chamber (the dropper bulb) in something other than flexible TPU filament - I printed this in PLA. It actually works pretty well as a dropper, although getting the dropper and bottle to print water-tight is a bit of a challenge.

The dropper has an integral tapered stopper which fits nicely into the little bottle. And the bottom of the bottle is tapered so that you can easily suck up the last drop. This dropper is probably fine for water, alcohol or light oil. Do not use it for your eyes - who know's what's in your filament?

Printer:

UDIO

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

UPDATE: I've uploaded a new version of the dropper (dropper.34mm.stl) that has a thinner wall on the bulb (0.34mm) but is designed to be printed with a 10% extrusion multiplier. This gives you a net wall thickness of 0.4mm (same as the original) but the rest of the dropper will be slightly over-extruded which will help give it to print water-tight.
.......

The hard part with this thing is to get it to print water-tight. The dropper bulb walls are a single perimeter in thickness, and the trick is to get your slicer to print each wall layer as a single, uninterrupted extrusion line. In Simplify3D, I had to set the line width to Automatic, as a fixed width setting of 0.4mm (which should have worked perfectly) produces layers with several connected sections. Make sure you use your previewer to make sure you've got single-path walls.

Beyond that, you want to print pretty hot and very slow. I printed this at 40mm/sec, but the perimeters were printed at 20mm/sec. If the dropper bulb is not water-tight (usually leaking at the corners) you can always use a drop of superglue to seal it up.

comments.text: PETG working perfectly for me at only 1  perimeter totally waterproof
comments.author: mrojod

comments.text: Excellent!  What temperature, print speed and layer thickness did you use with PETG?  I'm still struggling to get decent layer adhesion with PETG.
comments.author: mrojod

comments.text: I did some tests with Formfutura HDGlas and got my best results with Temps around 213-216°C with a 0.8mm nozzle 0.2mm Layerheight on the UM2 with a PLA Profile as base. Print speed was 40mm/s and travel speed 120mm/s.
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: Thanks a bunch for the specific details.  Are your outer perimeters at 40mm/s too, or are those done at a slower speed?  Also, are you running with a fan on the print or not?  I'll give these temps and speeds a shot - I think I might have just been trying to print too fast.
comments.author: drato

comments.text: The outermost Wall speed is 25mm/s, but inner walls are even faster by 53.3mm/s. I used PLA style settings, so normal fan speed 100%, no closed chamber.
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: Oh and if you have weak layer bonding in the end, no worries just put the part into the oven to anneal it. Try to stay lower then the glass transition temperature of the material to avoid warping and watch the part, too long in the oven is degrading it.
comments.author: drato

comments.text: Thanks again for all the details.  All of my problems have been with layer adhesion, but from your numbers, I'm guessing I'm printing way too fast.  I'll give your settings a shot.  Also quite interesting about the annealing, I wouldn't have guessed that you'd get improved adhesion if you were below the glass transition temp.  I'll give that a try too.  One last question: have you noticed much difference between different brands of PETG?  I tend to use cheap filament, so this could be another issue...
comments.author: drato

comments.text: Yes totally, different brands have different mixtures with different specs for the material, some are developed for easy printing, some for strength etc. So checking their info, best practice and data sheets is the first I do before starting to print, especially the recommended settings are important and around that I start testing. Cheap can be good but I had the experience that you should try to be in the golden middle, not too cheap but it also does not have to be too expensive. The rest comes with testing.
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: OK, maybe one more question.  I print mostly mechanical parts than can be large but need high precision, and I print almost exclusively in PLA.  I print very hot (~230C for PLA) with a ton of airflow so at 80mm/s, .2mm layers, I get very good layer-layer and line-line adhesion.  I keep hearing that PETG "prints as fast as PLA" but I've come nowhere close to this.  Do you know of any brands of PETG that are produce good layer adhesion at even 60mm/s, 0.2mm layers?  (Again, you are a great source of info - thanks!)
comments.author: drato

comments.text: :D Happy to be of help, I actually have no experience in pushing the limits of fast printing so far, so here unfortunately I cant help much. I am currently fiddling around with ClearScent ABS, and the parts come out really strong with a nice smooth finish.

comments.text: I've uploaded a new dropper (dropper.34mm.stl) that has a couple of changes.  I've adjusted the contours of the top and bottom sections of the bulb to help the slicer create a more water-tight set of perimeters, but I also redesigned it to be printed with a 10% extrusion multiplier which will over-extrude slightly to help fill gaps.  I ended up thinning the bulb wall from 0.4mm to 0.34mm so that with the 10% over-extrusion, you get a net wall thickness of the original 0.4mm.

I'm also going to try a version where the bulb walls are thinner, but then you bump up your extrusion multiplier to get you back to a 0.4mm wall.  This will then over-extrude everywhere else to help seal up the pin holes.

title: Logitech C520 webcam mounting adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I couldn't find anything already made for this webcam. I'm planning to connect it to my Raspberry Pi and mount it on my 3D printer to get time-lapses, maybe a bit of remote monitoring too.

This part is designed to fit tight the original mounting system from Logitech. Check out this video to find out how to take it a part gently. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ll-eA8FxqxY
This video (not by me) is for the C510 but they are similar webcam and same method of disassembly.

Included:
Mounting bracket for Creality CR-10 hotbed (need to be rotated in your slicer, I messed up with the plane when designing it) - One of the print will have to be mirrored (with your slicer) to have both left and right brackets.

Designed to be modular so fill free to design different mounting bracket or different camera adapter to fit on those bracket.

What you need to know for custom adapter/ mounting bracket:

  • The hole for the articulation has a diameter of 3.20mm (for tight M3 nylon screw fitting)
  • The thickness of the rounded articulation is 5mm (+/- your printer precision)
  • The "diameter" of the rounded articulation is 10mm

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These options are not really important. Just depends how good you want it to look like as finish product.

Assembly on the printer (CR-10)
  • Remove the 2 bed levelling knobs on the front of the printer.
  • Place both brackets down on the support of the heating bed, place back the spring, screw back the knobs.
  • All parts are designed to receive M3 screws and nuts, I have used M3x30 nylon screws and cut them once mounted (they are spare screws I had around cannot remember where I bought them)

title: MeGaTroN Cooler Fanduct Tevo Tarantula w BLTouch Remix

description.text:
Update 9/25/2017: Fixed height of the BLTouch mount issue.
If you printed the orginal use a 5mm spacer to correct the z-height of the sensor.

Offsets for the firmware that I have currently are as follows:

X -34
Y -5
Z-offset -1.20 (this is what I have worked out for mine, but each is different so please go through the full process to find your z-offset.

Loved this design by Paul0 and needed a BLTouch mount. I remixed it in TinkerCad by using the orginal MeGaTroN Fan duct and the orginal BLTouch mount and merged them together. When installed the lowest point of the fan ducts should be about the same as the pin on the BLTouch when it is in stored state. I'll post offsets as soon as I have it installed on my Tarantula.

Supports are not needed to print.

Printed with 0.4mm nozzle, using white PET-G from ColorFabb to get original look.
Flexibility of chosen material contributes to vibration dampening, which is barely visible on the recorded footage.

Kuro Alex (KA) Extruder, based on Alex Extruder.
I've modified from AA to KA, just for the sake of my nickname, instead of my name.
######################################
v1.1 SCAD Uploaded (not print tested)
  • Fixed some minor errors
  • Code cleaning
    ######################################
    I made this extruder so I could adapt Alex Extruder to my needs. I use it with 3mm filament, a MK7 as the drive gear and a J-Head hotend.
    As it was made on OpenSCAD, it's possible to easily modify the model. That said, I have to clean the code and make it easier to modify.
    The gears for Alex Extruder should work alright, so I won't post gears right now, since the gears I have are not exactly what I expected and they are not my code.
    I've included some work that's not mine in the .zip file for the ease of modifications. If it's your work and you want it removed, please just drop a word and I'll remove it asap.
    The following extra codes are included:
    Alex-Extruder_10_9mm_JHead.STL - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220493
    jhead.scad - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45379
    mk7.scad
    I don't really know who made mk7.scad, so I can't give the proper credits.
    Alex-Extruder_10_9mm_JHead.STL is the original file I based my design on.

These are models of the closed and open forms of the T4 bacteriophage DNA clamp. The "open form" occurs when the clamp is being loaded onto DNA by a "clamp loader" complex. "Enterobacteria phage T4 is a bacteriophage that infects Escherichia coli bacteria."
--http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enterobacteria_phage_T4 "The viral gp45 sliding clamp subunit protein contains two domains. Each domain consists of two alpha helices and two beta sheets -? the fold is duplicated and has internal pseudo two-fold symmetry. Three gp45 molecules are tightly associated to form a closed ring encircling duplex DNA."
--http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA_clamp The models are surface representations derived from PDB entries 1CZD and 3U60:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=1czd
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=3u60 STL files created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/

title: Star Trek Discovery - Phaser and Body Slice
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I updated the handle to this excellent Star Trek Discovery Phaser, fixed the finger grooves so the curve is better on both the front and rear. I also filled in the holes to allow more glue to bond with the body of the phaser.

IMHO, if you are a guy, you need to scale this phaser up 10-15%. The grip is very small and more suited for a woman's sized hand. In fact, it is so small that I think it's hard to hold.

Stardate - 47634.44, Updated with sliced Phaser body to help those with build volume height issues and when scaling to a larger weapon.

Update - Includes phaser emitter.

This is designed to stiffen and stabilize the CoreXY idle bearings shafts in order to stop them from slightly tilted when you tighten belts in order to get the maximum print quality from the machine.

Printing
You want to print this with PLA (stiffer) with at least 4 shells at the default orientation (laying sideway) to give them the maximum strength.

Modifications
STEP file is provided.

Also, you might want to join us at East3D Gecko facebook group.

I included the DesignSpark Mechanical file.

i ended up doing a lot more work on this model than i originally anticipated. i remodeled the shirt collar and added depth to the skirt, cuffs, collar. also manually joined cleavage to shirt to prevent non-manifold edges.
the hair is a bit of an afterthought because i'm burned out from working on this for too long. hopefully i'll get back to it and finish it properly once i find more patience.

known issues:

-hair front (bangs) have manifold issues and don't slice properly
-thin wall issues particularly in the shirt collar

i wouldn't print this if i were you... at least not yet. but if you do... scale it at least 3X to minimize thin wall issues.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

title: Modified Parts for Z18 Warhammer 40k Chainsword

description.text:
Update - September 11, 2017

Uploaded the following modified pieces:

  • A split version of the main body piece.
  • A split version of the main (shorter) handle.

These changes allow me to print at 100% on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus (200x200x180).

Details

I have modified some of the parts (update: most of the parts, except for the longer handle) for the excellent Z18 Warhammer 40k Chainsword - supportless assembly to fit on my Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus. I'm printing one of these (at 50%) as a companion to the Primaris Bolt Rifle & Pistol which I recently printed (you can see the print here).

NOTE: I have not modified all of the parts, so you will need to download the other pieces from the original project.

I'm initially printing these at 50% scale, so I don't know if these model files fit, at full scale, yet. I will check and adjust if need be before I'm done. First I'll finish the 50% model.

Modifications

I've split the main-chain.stl into three parts. I've also modified supports.stl to print horizontally. They now have a flat surface on one side, but this should not matter since they go inside the main-chain.stl piece.

Note that even at 50% scale, the supports.stl were too wide (printing horizontally) to fit on my print bed. That was easy enough. With a horizontal orientation, I scaled the Y and Z axis by 50% and the X axis by 25%. If printed twice, you can glue the supports or attach them some other way to create the full-length pieces.

Thanks VERY much to aaskedall for some VERY impressive full-sized models. Looking forward to whatever comes next!

description.text: This is a case for the TP-Link TL-WR703N which is being used by many hacking projects around. The router already comes with a compact case, but quite difficult to pry open. I modelled this case a few months ago to allow for easy hacking with a friction fit lid that can be popped off to get access to the serial ports and other components. It was mainly an exercise in getting the measurements right for future custom cases [uploading those tomorrow]. http://www.madox.net/

Case/Thing is in two pieces, should be relatively straight forward to print.
There is provision for two M2x4 mounting screws but they should not be necessary as the router PCB should sit fairly snug within the case.
Insert the router PCB with the Ethernet end first through the Ethernet hole in the case and then gently push down the other end of the PCB.  Secure with option M2x4 self tapping screws if required.
Removal is a bit tricky, I suggest you use angled tweezers at the mounting holes to pull the PCB out gently.

This thing is supposed to protect the battery of your Vortex 285 drone from your props, if the arms fold in!
The extra bumps on the side help to absorb lots of force.
It also protects the SMA connector, and the antenna in a crash.

I found it extremely worth printing; see the picture of the white one (previous revision) to see why! There's a 2-3mm deep gouge in the side! My battery would not have liked that..

Save your battery, print this today!

Fits up to 33mm thick batteries, higher version available upon request.

The one labeled "Printedplate" is for people who have printed a bottom/camera protector, which might be just a bit thicker. The normal one leaves 25mm room, this version gives 25.8mm. If you're unsure, use calipers!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

no

Notes:

Print with lots of shells/outlines, so the model is printed solid.
A raft is probably necessary for bed adhesion.
Print the item on it's side. Supports optional, but they help for rounded holes.

Mounting

The protector is supposed to need some "convincing" to attach to the drone; it'll snap over the screws at the bottom eventually. (or help it along with some prying!)

The antenna is supposed to go trough the big hole in the top, and is mostly protecting the SMA connector. The fillet does make sure it doesn't bend too sharply, though.
I leave my antenna on at all times. (transport in a padded foam box)

description.text: Fidget spinner

print_settings.Notes:: I printed mine at .2 layer height with PLA filament. Supports are required for front, back, and bracket. I printed the front and back parts facing up in an attempt to get a better finish on the outside of the parts, but the supports were terrible to remove from inside the back part. I would suggest printing it with the inside facing up so the supports are on the outside to make it easier to remove them. Neither the button nor the cap part requires supports if oriented with shaft pointing up. I suggest using a smaller nozzle to print the button if you care about the text being visible. My .4mm nozzle pretty much obliterated the text.

title: Tiltable Housing for LCD Controller - FT5 or other 2020 machine

description.text:
This housing is designed for the Folger Tech FT-5 in the lower right front corner to replace the stock melamine part. It should be usable on other printers built with 2020 type extrusion though. I liked RamonSeda's 2004 SMART DISPLAY 2020 MOUNT (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1894809), but I wanted one that could be tilted up and down. I also was looking for a little more varied mounting options for a future printer project.

This housing can be mounted on the top, bottom, left, or right by turning or printing a mirrored version of the bracket. It will tilt up or down to make it easier to see the display and it fully encloses the pcb to provide better protection. The reset button is recessed a bit to prevent it from being accidentally pushed.

The stock cables were barely long enough - it would be good to replace them with longer cables if possible, but not required. The cables are routed through the bracket into the housing where they connect to the pcb. I'm using the stock knob for now. I may print a new one later.

I used the stock 5mm hardware to attach the bracket to the frame. I purchased a #10-32 threaded rod from Menards and glued it into the shaft with about 3/4" or so sticking out the end to thread a nut onto. (I used a knurled nut also from Menards) To assemble the front and back together, I used #4 x 1" long screws through the back and pcb into the front.

The SolidWorks files are included if you would like to modify it.

Printer:

Folger Tech FT-5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed mine at .2 layer height with PLA filament. Supports are required for front, back, and bracket. I printed the front and back parts facing up in an attempt to get a better finish on the outside of the parts, but the supports were terrible to remove from inside the back part. I would suggest printing it with the inside facing up so the supports are on the outside to make it easier to remove them. Neither the button nor the cap part requires supports if oriented with shaft pointing up. I suggest using a smaller nozzle to print the button if you care about the text being visible. My .4mm nozzle pretty much obliterated the text.

title: Perspex Clear Acrylic WS2812 LED Audio Interactive Light Bar

description.text:
Perspex LED light and sound activated bar
Completed Assembly in operation: https://youtu.be/d8P9hhyOXbk and another sample https://youtu.be/7bf3BYers34
I apologize for the low quality video.It looks and the sound was much better than my tablet cam gives justice.

Material:

1 IKEA Moslanda 115cm picture shelf (black)
1 Arduino Uno
1 Transformer
2 1M 30 Pixel/M WS2812 LED strips (total of 52 LEDs required)
26 3/4" Thick Perspex Cast Acrylic Blocks 5" x 3"
1 MAX9814 Microphone Amplifier Module AGC Auto Gain Control for Arduino
1 470 ohm resistor
1 100 uf capaitor
1 0.1 uf capacitor
1 Rocker Switch Package (L x W x H) 5.0 x 2.8 x 0.8 in. (see picture)
1 Pushbutton Switch Package (L x W x H) 2.4 x 1.4 x 1.2 in. (see picture)
1 48 in. x 3/4 in. x 1/16 in. Aluminum Square Tube
10 #8 Pan Head Sheet Metal Screws

Printables:

26 Perspex Mount*
8 Led Strip Retainer
2 Center Support
1 Left Angular End
1 Right Angular End
1 Center Connection Junction
1 Arduino Screwless Hobby Top
1 Arduino Uno Mountable Bottom

Attention was paid to ensuring all pieces will print without support. There are fine design details to enhance FDM bridging abilities.

*Perspex is cast clear acrylic and as such will vary slightly in thickness. 3 Mount widths are provided to match to the width of your pieces for a snug fit. Before printing you must measure the thickness of each block and print the appropriate width to fit.

Constructing this is undeniably an undertaking but I never underestimate the maker community's willingness to create astoundingly complex and wonderful things. I posted the entire circuit diagram and sketch to Autodesk Circuit but in my attempt to link it, it appears to have vanished in the move to Tinkercad. If there is enough interest I will recreate it on Tinkercad as well as discuss the assembly process. You will need an accurate means to saw finely cut slots in the IKEA shelf as this forms the basis for mounting and aligning the block retainers. There's a few skills involved but nothing insurmountable. Other than the cuts and soldering, everything else snaps,slides or screws together.

Update: With a little bit of searching Autodesk Circuits I found my design post with a very early version of the sketch. For whatever reason Autodesk assigned it to a fictitious author in a failed attempt to migrate me over to Tinkercad. None the less it provides the general circuit layout. The signal generator shown is only to provide an input for running the simulation and is not required as input comes from the audio input of the MAX9418 in the real world. Since posting this circuit the bar additionally has 4 modes that are selected by the momentary push button wired to pin 2 not shown in the circuit diagram.

Note the revised sketch and light bar design uses 13 WS2812 per strip versus the 12 shown in the circuit diagram.

https://circuits.io/circuits/4038568-arduino-neopixels

Attribution to Robert Robert on Youtube who provided the design inspiration and original sketch which resulted in this 3d printed version of it and the modified sketch.

Here is the copy of the version of sketch it's currently running. (link to Dropbox)

https://db.tt/7CaKQTiyJn

title: Another Prusa i3 Geeetech Spool Holder

description.text:
I made this spool holder for my geeetech prusa i3. It is capable to hold two spools (depending on length of the threaded rod).

I had some 20x20mm aluminum profiles left, which I cut down to a length of 245mm each. Any cheap profile from a hardware store will do. The holes for the 20x20 profiles in the printed parts are oversized (i guess I used 21 x 21). If its too loose for you, you could perhaps use some glue. I just stuck the profiles in and it works totally fine without any glue.

I used an M8 threaded rod with Z809 (608) ball bearings in combination with the cone shaped holder to be able to use different spool sizes.

I really dig this construction. Frictionless feeding! The filament spool even moves backwards at retractions! :)

I also design a filament guide (see picture). It has a 5,6mm gap to be stuck on the acrylic frame. I used some paper beneath to make it sit firm.

Hope you like the design!

Notes:

I printet the parts for the 20x20 profile at an 45° angle so that no supports were necessary for the holes. I used a brim to compensate the smaller contact area to the print bed.

Because i'm soldering out electrical parts to reuse them, I need a solution to get them sorted. First I "designed" one of these seperator-cards, but then I took the decision, that placing boxes in the box is much more useful. - So I can easily take one single box out, I can resort them quickly and I can place a sticker on it. <- That's useful, because i'm going to use barcodes and a software to get an index.

I got many parts in small amounts, so I decided to build a box, which fits 4 times in the original box. I build a "6 time box" as well, but you can't handle it usefully, without empty the whole box or using tweezers.

The original assortment box I bought at „Hornbach“. It’s a german hobbymarket / building suppy store / hardware store. The assortment box got no brand name. It’s just labeled with „Made in Germany“.

Bis zu drei Unterteilungen pro Box sind möglich. Fünf „Trenner“ sind im Lieferumfang enthalten. Sie lassen sich in 10er-Paketen nachbestellen für etwa 3€ pro Stück. Das ist für mich nicht tragbar, da das Sortiment 36 Schubladen umfasst, von der jede theoretisch dreifach unterteilt werden kann.

Da ich elektronische Bauteile für Wiederverwendung aus alten Geräten auslöte und aufbewahre, möchte ich sie vernünftig sortiert wissen. Zunächst designte ich einen dieser „Trenner“, musste aber feststellen, dass das kein für mich gangbarer Weg ist. Ich erstellte also Boxen, die in die Schublade des Sortiments passten. So kann ich eine Box einfach entnehmen und alle auch einzeln beschriften. <- Das ist in meinem Fall sinnvoll, da ich die Boxen noch mit Barcodes beschriften und einer Software katalogisieren werde.

print_settings.Notes:: Use 3 top and bottom layers.  The only thing with infill is the small lip for stacking

description.text:
I love countspatula's tray design where you can pour the parts back into a baggie or storage container. I have printed several and use them all the time. I always wished they were stackable. So I made a version that was stackable.

This part is also optimized for 0.4 mm print nozzles. The walls are an integer multiple of 0.4 mm and print exactly with 2 shells. These optimizations cut printing time in half!

The base is designed to print at 0.28 mm layer height (instead of 0.3 mm). Many 3D printer motors have a 0.04 mm z-axis stepper resolution. They can move to other positions, but the motor is holding between steps and is not stable. When using an integer multiple of 0.04 mm for z-axis layer height, the layers are much cleaner and have better layer-to-layer adhesion.

You can watch timelapse videos here: https://youtu.be/nWBk2_kmrwQ https://youtu.be/lXnrs0QPYfQ

UPDATE: 9/11/2017 Added a 50 mm x 50 mm tray in addition to the standard 50 mm x 100 mm tray.

UPDATE: 9/15/2017 Added a 50 mm circular tray.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with ABS, I'd recommend using a large brim if you are printing on a printer without an enclosure.

description.text:
I had an idea for an enclosure and as is so incredibly common, I found timkloss had the idea first so I decided to use that model and make a bunch of tweaks.

I wanted to test the Windows 10 3D Builder application and as a result this entire project was remixed using only that tool. Please refer to the included .3mf and .obj files for specific details. In the .3mf file, the black pieces will need to be acquired from the original design by timskloss as those are unchanged; the white piece is onlsy slightly changed as it was reported as having a defect and thus fixedby 3D Builder.

For my enclosure, I used .040" clear PETG. The surround is 993mm x 708mm the door is 490mm X 693mm (your dimensions may vary slightly). I acquired a full sheet for ~$55 from www.alroplastics.com

The surround/door frame is made using 4 pieces of 1/4" AL plywood edge (2x 70cm, 2x 68.5cm, again, your measurements may vary).

The door closure contains 12 8mm x 3mm neodymium magnets, 2 per hole and alternating polarity. These magnets can be found just about anyplace, mine were from Amazon and were lerft over from another project.

For the door hinge, I used 2 30cm piano hinges, screw holes were counter-sunk and I printed a bunch of MagnetShimx3 to screw into (1 per screw)

"Gapped" and "Notched" tabs should be used on the top of the top and the bottom of the bottom, "Shallow" tabs are used against the wooden plates (i.e. Extruder/ Display). Use whatever number works for you.

I printed this in ABS on my Prusa i3 Mk2s (it already has an enclosure) and almost every joint is "glued" using an ABS/Acetone slurry. the tabs are secured using 6mm and 12mm long 3mm screws with lock nuts.

In retrospect, I feel I should have combined more pieces before printing them (door corners) to add more strength but it isn't 100% needed.

The thermometer enclosure comes from Noircogi's design and was scale for this thermometer: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M5BCIFR
The model with a Molex connect has a wide input voltage range and can be wired in directly, I used Kapton tape to secure the probe to the underside of top of the printer.
I also filled the hole so that I can easily print it and use it for my other 2 printers, just drill a hole where needed.

Please leave any questions in the comments, especially if I seem to have left out any details, I made the pieces as I needed them and almost certainly omitted something.

Just bought a new Canon camcorder and it came with a "Mini Advanced Shoe", which meant all my standard attachments wouldn't fit.  
It's not a powered adaptor and has a void for the connections on the camcorder.
I used Cinema 4D r14 to construct the model, with a digital caliper to get the fine measurements needed.  I've included the c4d file as well as the stl.

comments.text: Looks great, works great! The little tabs are a bit prone to breaking when made from PLA, but that is mostly due to the fact that the required geometry doesn't lend itself well to non-isotropic manufacturing methods. That design flaw is on whoever decided to make this silly little miniature hot shoe in the first place! I was as surprised as anyone to realize that a normal shoe wouldn't fit the slot, and I was sure glad to not have to grab my calipers to fix the issue! Thanks for the share! It sure got me out of a bind!

This bottle pourer was designed for my beloved chili oil. Now I can regulate the amount of that hot stuff much better and hopefully wont spoil entire meals any more. The design fitted my bottles perfectly from the beginning. If someone wants to test it out he/she can customize the parameters easily in the provided .scad file. Just measure the inside diameter of your bottle with a caliper and adjust the variable "plugDia" in the openscad script accordingly. I added some small ridges to the plug that enters the bottle in order to provide a seal like I have seen on plastic corks. Please drop me a note when you print it and let me know how it turned out ....

After months of annoying fiddling with my XT60 connector on my ZMR250, I finally got fed up and designed this handy mount. Unlike the other XT60 mounts, this XT60 mount has a very simple, and therefore, very universal design. It is designed to slide over the rear 5mm (OD) aluminium standoffs and hold your XT60 connector in a place where your wires won't get sucked into your props. Note that a little hot glue may be necessary on the bottom of the mount to ensure the XT60 doesn't slide out.

Total weight: 12g (including antenna mount)

Don't have a 3D printer? No problem! Purchase it on eBay!

Updates
9/23/17: Added additional SMA/RPSMA antenna mount that slides over the standoffs after the XT60 mount. Note that this will add approximately 3g of extra weight to bring the total up to roughly 12g.

My wife was looking for a lid holder for all her lids. i couldn't find one here so i decided to model my own. I iterated it 4 times so far. the Holey version is the latest, it prints the fastest, and uses the least filament.

Notes:

printing the half solid was nerve-wracking for my as that 2 mm x 15 mm tower does not connect until it is way way up in the air. I would probably print either the solid or holey in the future and skip the half. For the smallest lids I'd use a 2.5" gap for the largest lids I used a 3.5"
To print two you will want to use the mirror function in your slicing software to create the second side

This is a remix from the L6 40 Italian tank. It is scaled to approximately 1/72.

The Semovente L. 40 da 47/32 was an Italian self-propelled gun built during World War II. It was created by mounting a Cannone da 47/32 anti-tank gun in an open-topped, box-like superstructure on a L 6/40 light tank chassis. Some were built as command tanks with a radio installed instead of the main gun. An 8 mm machine gun disguised as the 47 mm main gun was used on these versions to make them look like a regular Semovente 47/32s. About 300 Semoventi da 47/32 were built from 1941 onward. The Semovente da 47/32 was the most heavily armed Italian armoured fighting vehicle used on the Eastern Front.

remixed_from.author: 3DCentralVA
remixed_from.title: Spinning Life Counter with Numbers and Indicator

description.text:
Remix from 3DCentralVA design https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:738511

Its basically just a counter which can be used and all sorts of environments. I use these for board games, doing inventory, or just having a why to remember a certain value [ I have a bit of short term memory]. And having more then two dials allows me to track numbers greater than 2 digits.

I included a center indicator so I wouldn't need the end caps making it a bit more compact and added a notch in the center of the dials so the center pin clicks into place making it easy to daisy-chain them together. In theory you could make them as long as you want by simply making the center pin longer or Shorter. I also included a closed version of the dials for those with OCD and don't want to see a hole on the end.

I used a brim on the center pins but no supports are need for the dials or indicators. All printed in the orientation they are in the STL files.

The ones shown in the pictures was a quick and dirty print just to make sure all of the notches lined up. I may have had the speed a bit high causing some under extruding on some of the parts.

Sizing the holes
I used a .5 wall thickness making the holes slightly smaller then they needed to be that why I could take a micro file and adjust them to the tension that I perfer. I like having the indicator very snug. This allows the indicators to stay in place while I turn the dials but at the same time having the dials somewhat fitted so they don't spin freely.

Edit:The notch within the holes are deeper so this does not effect the way the pin clicks into place

description.text:
Travail avec le logiciel libre "Structure Synth" pour créer une coupe !

/*
Corbeille
Fichier corbeille_5.es

Auteur      Jean-Pierre Perroud  ( jpp )
Création    09-09-2017  /  jpp
Modif       09-09-2017 /  jpp

*/

//set raytracer::size [1920x1080] // Full HD TV
set raytracer::size [3840x2160] // UHD TV
set background #023
set maxdepth 16 // profondeur des calculs

{ rz 0 s 1 } r0

rule r0 {
4 { rz 120 } R1
4 { rz 120 } R2
}

rule R1 {
{ x -1.3 rz 1.618 rz 6 ry 13 s 0.99 hue 0.01 sat 0.999 } R1
{ s 4 a 1 blend red 0.4 } box
}

rule R2 {
{ x -1.3 rz 1.618 ry 6 s 0.99 hue 0.099 sat 0.999 } R2
{ s 4 a 1 blend white 0.4} box
}

// Fin du code - jpp

description.text:
Memento Mori - remember that you will die

This is a visual representation of the number of days in 75 years of life, approximately how many days I have left to live if I should live to be 100.

I understand that this is a bit morbid but I think it's an important reflection to make from time to time, remembering that life is finite and that we should make the most of every day.

This can can be a motivator to live life to the fullest and do the things you've always wanted to do, because one day you won't have any days left..

description.text: Orchid clamp to hold flowers in place - this was requested by my girlfriend
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3l702uby3qg

This is an experimental set of printable machine parts, the idea being that you can configure these into whatever 3-or-fewer-axis machine you want. The basic parts are: 1) Linear rail and ball carriage.
2) Rack and pinion
3) Structural blocks with 2 (angle), 3, 4, and 5 mating faces. Hole patterns for all parts are NEMA 17 - 31mm square, and holes are sized for M4 fasteners. With the right tool holders it should be possible to make a small milling machine, drilling machine, maybe a pick-and-place machine, who knows? I invite people to please post suggestions or modifications. Notes: 1) I haven't printed any of these yet, but I have skeinforged them, so I think they'll print ok.
2) I haven't arranged multiple parts into one file so they can be printed together, but it would be smart to do this. I'll post assembled files when I get a chance.
3) I don't know how accurate the resulting machine will be, so please keep in mind that this is still something of a work in progress. I hope to add and anti-backlash split gear as a start, but I'd love to hear other suggestions.

1) Determine the machine configuration you want
2) Print the various parts required
3) Drill and tap the pinion setscrew location and the end cap fastening holes in the rail car body - I was thinking M3 fasteners.
4) Assemble the rail cars with 5mm ball bearings - be sure to lubricate them
5) Assemble the remaining parts, making sure to key the rack and rails together.

author: Jacks-3D-Printing

description.text:
Pump Aid for Gamo-P900

If you have one, you know the front sight is a killer on the palm of your hand. This takes care of that in addition to increasing the leverage for pumping.

Just slip it onto the gun all the way so the inner-boss sits inside the front-sight.

Some folks have difficulty printing Radius’ on bottoms and overhangs, this part has mostly Chamfers with small radius for edge smoothing.

Print Tips:

Bottom Layer = 3
Top Layer = 3
Shells = 3
Infill pattern: Cross-hatch (depends on your printer/software - photo shows settings for Simplify3D to accomplish cross-hatching)
Print Height = 0.3mm or less (saves time Vs 0.2)

You shouldn’t need supports for the short ‘straight’ overhang-area if your process is dialed in (a Temp of 230C will enable bonding of strands and produce a nice part). See photo.

Sand/smooth the Ejection Mark-Flashing marks on you gun if they interfere.

title: Customisable card box and draw/discard pile holder

This is a mortar I made based off of the real life 60mm M2 HE Mortar round. This type of mortar round was used by 60mm mortar crews and was light, portable, and most importantly deadly. Back to the 3D model... This is 50mm in diameter meaning you can shoot it from 2 inch schedule 40 PVC (that is if you have a cannon for it). There are 3 basic parts to this mortar which are the fins, body, and fuse which are threaded so that you can screw them together. I am a WWII geek and love making stuff like this. Hope you enjoy this build.
INCLUDES: Body, Fins, And fuse respectively... Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: pshax
remixed_from.title: Headrest Eye / curry hook / seat hanger thing!

description.text:
Two of my friends, with 2 young children, liked the pram cup holder I printed a while back & I found the pram cargo hooks which seemed a great idea. However the place they needed them most was in the car. I found a great seat-back hanger which used the headrest rods as anchors, but they used d-clips which were a bit noisy for the babies and too awkward to use to hang e.g. a nappy bag on when a sudden change was needed during a long car trip. So I combined the best bits of the 2 designs...

The design is in 2 parts so that the layer lines run with, not across, the lines of highest load, and so the parts are going to be strongest this way. It also allows for the part most likely to fail over time, the hook, to be replaced more quickly and cheaply. Further, it allows for the use of a more springy material like PLA+ or PETG for the main body. Though ideally keep the hook as PLA or ABS so it can take the weight of heavy shopping bags or full nappy sacks without bending... The 2 parts are very tight and require quite a push to seat together - make sure the screw holes line upwell before joining with M5 16mm machine screws (pan or button head). The screw will form it's own thread though a lot of torque is needed. It doesn't need a nut as the thread is more than tight enough to prevent the screw backing off, and it is only hold the parts together - the flats of the parts are what prevents the hook rotating. My prototype had a nut, but it just added complexity and expense for no clear gain in strength.

The length of the arm was designed around the skoda & vw seats but should fit most modern car seats with removable headrests. The holes are a smidgen under 14mm which is a snug fit, but they can be drilled out quite a lot more if required, if you print with 4+ walls. I added a curved not straight gusset to the hook to avoid leaving a dent in the piping of the seats.

description.text:
This is a holder for one of the "180x industrial microscope lens" that you see on AliExpress

It fits around the 50mm ring and takes three M3 bolts (I use 9mm length) to secure it so that you can rotate the zoom ring.

On one side there is a hole to take an M8 threaded rod, which you should probably tap rather than force in. If you look at the scad there's a rotate(30) which basically rotates the 3 holes around the ring, should you want to move them in relation to the M8 hole.

There's also a a T-piece (cube with two holes in!) to take a vertical rod and nut to move the camera+lens up/down to focus.

See also my related CS mount adaptor and lamp clip and RaspberryPi ZeroW CS mount case

description.text:
This is a remix of rickym1970's original 7 LED light bar. This is a 24 volt light bar and needs a 330 Ohm resistor in series with the LEDs to prevent them getting overloaded.

In the first picture the 330 Ohm resistor is concealed within the black heat shrink in the red wire. This is an earlier prototype just for the record. But it illustrates the principle well enough.

Why choose this one? It is reinforced so that it does not flop in the heat making PLA a sensible choice.

The LEDs are standard 5 mm high brightness white LEDs

The improvements are that the original had a tendency to flop due to the heat softening the PLA.

This is a small 45 degree LED mount for my ANET A8 IKEA Lack table enclosure.
They should fit on any 90 degree corner and could be used to mount anything you wanted to be directed towards the build area (camera, lights, etc) I wanted something to mount the
Flexible LED Strips to Rigid Strips by dBECHTOLD
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536648
to the
Lack Case - Stands - Anet A8 by Bobby87x
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2137804

Mounting the LED strips up high above the print bed cast a lot of shadows on the part being printed. I found that the best way for the LED strips light up the part being printed was to be in front and shining onto the part level with the print bed. I wired the LED strips to a individual switch and the 12VDC ANET A8 power supply so I can turn them on/off. One LED strip on the front right and one on the front left illuminates the whole print area completely.

I used super glue to attach the 45 degree mount to the LED strips and the Lack table stands.

description.text:
I really liked the design of the USB holder, but found that as others had pointed out with the first (taller) design, there were at least 3 layers missing when using Slicer. So I printed the lower poly version but the side slots for the SD and Micro SD cards are so close that it's awkward to get them in and out.

I decided to see if I could fix the taller design so Slicer wouldn't miss layers.

I tried with netFabb first but that crashed every time on export after the repair.

So instead I imported the original file into Tinkercad, exported it back out as an STL file, loaded that into netFabb, repaired the layers, then exported the design. It worked out perfect.

I posted the fix here but the awesome design credit goes to the original creator!

Oh, also, I changed the mounting holes as I found the countersunk versions were placing the bracket under a lot of lateral stress at the mounting point as opposed to pushing directly on to the mounting hole wall. Use a pan head (or similar) screw, and even a washer, to spread the load better and make for a more secure mounting.

author: Aussie_Jo

title: Cryptex for Betrayal at House on the Hill
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is a parametric multi-rotor "cryptex" used to keep track of Betrayal at House on the Hill character scores. This "cryptex" is not a real cryptex in that it isn't a puzzle or lock of any kind although it looks similar to a cryptex. The rotors independently rotate about a central core indexed such that the faces click into position such that one face is always aligned to the "top".

Included in this thing is a ruby program that creates a set of Betrayal at House on the Hill (http://avalonhill.wizards.com/games/betrayal-at-house-on-the-hill) game cryptex label(s). The labels need to be printed and glued to the rotors of the cryptex.

Note that two M4 bolts are used to hold the cryptex together.

The game is for three to six players who choose from twelve characters so at most six full cryptexes are usable during game play. Creating a full set of twelve rotors (with character names and scores) allow players to choose their favourite and quickly reset a cryptex by unscrewing a bolt and replacing the rotors.

Assembly Instructions

The cryptex consists of a central 6 sided axle, a "core" with a number of integral flippers that provide the rotor indexing, a "rotor" with labels on it which rotates around the core, "endcaps" that mark which rotor face is selected and "boltcaps" that hold the whole thing together. The core has built-in supports for your 3D printer that needs to be removed - the support material is grey in OpenSCAD to make it easier to see. The boltcaps need to be glued to a M4x16mm bolt (note that different bolts could be used - there is a commented out example of a 1/4" bolt in the cryptex.scad file).

To assemble the cryptex, slide the cores onto the axle ensuring all of the cores are aligned the same way, slide the rotors on the cores, slide an endcaps onto each end ensuring that the face of the endcap and rotors align and finally screw a boltcap (with bolt) into the axle. Note that you may find that tapping the thread in the axle, either with a tap and die set or just with the bolt itself allows for smooth change of rotor sets during game play.

To apply the labels to the rotors, print the labels, cut them to strips - note the cut marks on the labels to help with this - and glue them to the rotors. In the build shown, Avery Ink Jet Sticker Project Paper (3383) was used to avoid having to apply glue to the back of the labels. To get a seamless joint of the label when wrapped around the rotor, allow the ends of the label to overlap, carefully cut through both layers of the label at once then remove the extra ends and press the ends back in place (cutting the labels this way can be dangerous, don't try this if you aren't able to do it safely).

Design Details

The cryptex is designed in OpenSCAD as a parameterized thing allowing easy modification for other uses. The number of rotors, sizes and number of faces (and more) are all parameters one can easily change.

Included in this thing is an OpenSCAD wedge.scad file that is used as a library component. It creates a pie shaped object which is generally useful when working with cylindrical objects. Put this file into the directory shown when in OpenSCAD under File->Show Library Folder...

This thing uses Dan Kirshner's thread library: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1938150

In the spirit of generating things with code, the labels are generated with a ruby program which uses the ruby port of imagemagick. The backgrounds to the labels are randomly generated so you might want to try generating them several times until the background is a shade you like. The program support command line arguments (use the -h option for help) to generate labels for a single character if you are happy with some but not all of the labels. The numbers and names applied to the labels are easy to edit if you'd like to generate a custom version of the cryptex.

description.text:
Crowd Sourcing flickr images to create 3D files. This is a working proof of concept. Long story short...
I didn't go to Washington DC to 3D scan the Lincoln Memorial.
Instead, I scanned flickr for all related images to "Lincoln Memorial statue" and downloaded the originals.
By uploading it to 123d catch, I was able to receive a 3D model of Abraham Lincoln's Face.

Here are my plans for a fully automated 3D generator based off of crowd sourced photography.
  • Parse Flickr with Search phrase
  • Download first 100 photos
  • Upload to 123d Catch
  • Download 3D model
    • Simple enough.
    Hopefully google can integrate this into their search engine in a few years (or months).

title: Cloud magnetic key shelf for car key fob

description.text: I'd seen a neat idea where a cloud shaped key holder used magnets to hold a bunch of keys decoratively on the wall (kudos due here: http://www.suck.uk.com/products/cloud-keyholder/?search=cloud). The only problem with that solution is that at home we don't keep our car key fobs on a ferrous keyring and since the metals in the fobs themselves are non-magnetic, we needed a little pocket in the back of the cloud.

• Printed on a RepRapPro Mendel in PLA.
  • The bottom slot is for some ebay sourced cuboid (30x10x3mm) rare-earth magnets.
  • The curved slot above the magnet slot is for some optional metal shielding/redirection for the keyfobs (http://www.kjmagnetics.com/blog.asp?p=shielding-materials. A quick google search did not determine if magnetic fields could actually damage a cars keyfob).
  • The keyfob shelf is big enough for either a VW keyfob, or a Volvo one so I suspect most keyfobs will fit (I don't own enough vehicles to test it with more).
  • Cloud can be mounted either with double sided foam tape or with a pair of nails (or both as I have done)
    • Photos of the installed cloud to come.

description.text:
This is a file I will use when testing whether I've resolved problems with my printer drawing circles.

I had to scale the design to 130% to have a single perimeter print for all circles. Please scale it to suit the nozzle that you're using so that only a single perimeter is made for each circle.

I hope this will allow me to clearly see that I've finally fixed the problem after printing a few models which had flat sided circles.

I will not be showing my resulting prints for this design. It'll probably also show up any height differences in the central area of the bed surface!

title: AA Battery Holder with charge indicator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Yes, another AA holder. My flash uses 4 batteries and often on a shoot I'll have 28 or 32 batteries with me. This holder has a built in selector switch so you can mark each batch of 4 to be 'OK' to use or 'X' don't use. This way, when I reach in my camera bag, I can tell if a batch is ready to go into my flash or not and the battieries that comes out of the flash can be set to 'X' so when I get home, I know exactly which needs a charge.

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

Yes

Notes:

I printed these with the battery side facing up so that there are no supports printed in there. This means that the outside needs to be cleaned. It is easier to work on outside edges than inner edges. If you think your printer can bridge the gaps, perhaps you can get away with no supports... Up to you but I recommend support.

The little PosStainfRelief part is not strictly necessary, but, if you want you can fit it to the inside of the top bracket. I did not bother printing it.

If it's not obvious, the elastic band goes through the middle of the components and hooks on the selector knob and the protrusion on the bottom. See the photos.

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

print_settings.Notes:: Designed for 1/4" OD Polyethylene tubing.

title: Formbot T-Rex 2+ Bowden Adapter Carriage Caps

description.text:
These models accompany a 1/4" PE tubing filament feed setup for the Formbot T-Rex 2+. The caps are mirrored for application on the left and right extruders, and each accepts one 1/4" push-connect fitting in the top, via 1/8" NPT threads. A tapered tunnel extends down from the fitting and onto the board, to reliably guide filament for insertion.

1/4" tubing was chosen to allow loose, low friction travel for the filament. Bowden tubing forms a tighter restriction and produces drag on the filament.

Buy the push-connect fittings here: https://www.mcmaster.com/#7880t145/=19b8sgv

Work the fittings into the finished part slowly, backing out frequently to stretch and wear the two pieces together, as it is a tight fit.

100 micron layer height in PETG worked well, this part does require supports.

Printer:

Formbot T-Rex 2+

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 Micron

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Wear in the fitting slowly to avoid delaminating the female threads in the part.

Requires Support.

Designed for 1/4" OD Polyethylene tubing.
Remove supports and clean artifacts from inside the filament guide, to ensure smooth travel.

print_settings.Infill:: 50% but you can probably get away with a bit less

title: X-axis tensioner for use with toothed idler.

description.text:
I recently released a x tensioner for use with my own x axis parts. This version is based upon the same design but with a few modifications to suit a stock x axis on the Anet A8 (The version with ABS printed x axis sides though it may work with the injection moulded parts too!)

This is oriented as intended for printing with supports built in. You will need to cut away the supports on the underside of the two prongs, the supports inside the central rectangular hole and most (not all) of the cylinder in the center.

You should ideally leave an equal amount of the central cylinder on either side such that the idler wheel is barely able to move from side to side but can rotate freely when mounted.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm nozzle and 0.32mm layer (0.2 would also be fine!)

Infill:

50% but you can probably get away with a bit less

Supports will need to be removed from the model after printing and before fitting. You will also need 3 sets of m3 screw and nut to hold the idler in place and fit to the top and bottom of the part to allow you to adjust the screws to tweak the tension in the x axis belt.

A few modifications on a previous OpenSCAD design used in my version of the x axis idler and motor mounts. Slightly thicker walls to accomodate recesses for nut and screw head on the idler hole, thinner prongs due to available space and slightly increased gap for the idler to be mounted.

title: Strong Drawing Machine XY base for external rails
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a modification of the Drawbot Drawing Machine XY carriage base by www.thingiverse.com/thing:1517211 (et. al.) This mod make the base much stronger with greater distortion resistance to bending when the size of the plot and rods are greater than A4.

The design supports the XY carriage to Float on external C rails attached to the sides of a 42x42mm run of wood. Attached to the top side of the wood are styrene I-beams that support 19mm convex drawer slider wheels that mount on M4 screws. One of these each attaches to the bottom of the carriage with a screw hole manually drilled out at the position of each former linear bearing. The hole is drilled through manually to allow for custom offsets for differing track and wheel sizes. The solution is similar to the system now used on the Axidraw 3 by Evil Mad Scientist with better alignment and less torquing of the carriage.

My goal is to produce a drawing machine with a large plot space using 350x8mm rods (A5 or larger). This base is my attempt at a hybrid carriage with one set of outside rails for Y and the x axis on rods. More here as I develop success...
https://www.facebook.com/kenno.mcdonnell

sensor housing for humidity probe

I have a few samples of ink for my fountain pen. I was always worried that I would accidentally tip one over when refilling my fountain pen. I designed this little thing in tinkercad (you can find the file here if you want to remix it in tinkercad: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9iLXI0io5zF) so that I can put my ink sample in it, refill my pen, and not worry so much about it tipping over. As a bonus, you can also put your pen in it when you dont have an ink sample in it.

The hole is slightly bigger than the width of the ink sample vial, this makes the ink sample easier to get in and out.

The pen in the pic is a Jinhao 992. It fits pretty well in it and there is some wiggle room. Feel free to remix this to your hearts content, as I would love to see what everyone comes up with. Also, this would probably be great in some clear filament so that you are able to see the level of ink in the vial.
